title: 110_hr3033
content: The Act titled "Contractors and Federal Spending Accountability Act of 2008" establishes a database for contracting officers and suspension and debarment officials. The "Contractors and Federal Spending Accountability Act of 2008" establishes a database maintained by the Administrator of General Services for information on integrity and performance of persons awarded Federal contracts and grants. The database covers any person awarded a Federal contract or grant if information exists regarding civil or criminal proceedings for the most recent 5-year period. The "Contractors and Federal Spending Accountability Act of 2008" requires the disclosure of any findings of fault resulting in restitution payments of $5,000 or more to the Federal or State government, terminated contracts and grants, suspensions, debarments, and administrative agreements with the Federal Government or State government. The "Contractors and Federal Spending Accountability Act of 2008" mandates the disclosure of findings of fault leading to restitution payments of $5,000 or more, terminated contracts, suspensions, debarments, and administrative agreements with the Federal or State government. The database must be designed to allow Federal agencies to input and update information promptly and accurately regarding actions taken against contractors or grant recipients. The database must allow for timely input of information, notification to relevant individuals, and the ability to add comments. It will be available to all federal agencies and the public through the General Services Administration website, with exemptions for certain information. The public availability of information exempt from disclosure under section 552(b) of title 5, United States Code. Prior to awarding a contract or grant, officials must review a database established under section 2 and document the present responsibility of prospective awardees with multiple judgments or convictions within a 3-year period for similar offenses. Additionally, disclosure in applications is required under section 4. Federal regulations will be amended to require disclosure of information in applications for Federal grants or contracts. This applies to contracts and grants above a certain threshold. An interagency committee will have a role in the process. The Interagency Committee on Debarment and Suspension is responsible for resolving lead agency issues, coordinating actions among agencies, promoting cooperative efforts, recommending changes to the suspension and debarment system, and authorizing the issuance of guidelines by the Office of Management and Budget. The Interagency Committee on Debarment and Suspension is responsible for implementing recommendations, authorizing subcommittees, and submitting an annual report to Congress on progress and efforts to improve the suspension and debarment system. The term "Interagency Committee on Debarment and Suspension" is defined as a committee constituted under Executive Order 12549. SEC. 6. Any Federal agency not covered by Executive Order 12549 can participate in the suspension and debarment system. SEC. 7. Funds are authorized for the General Services Administrator to establish the required database. SEC. 8. A report to Congress is mandated. SEC. 8. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Administrator of General Services must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will list databases with Federal contracting and grant information and provide recommendations for creating a centralized database.
